question.query: what are the top trending assets on Solana

content.title: Top Major Assets on Solana 24h Trading Volume
content.description: A screenshot of a market data dashboard displaying the top major assets on the Solana blockchain over a 24-hour period. The table lists six tokens: Solana (SOL), Bitcoin (CBBTC), Ethereum (WETH), Zcash (ZEC), Monad (MON), and Hyperliquid (HYPE). Solana (SOL) leads with a price of $135.14 (+2.5%), a market cap of $76.12B, and a dominant 24-hour trading volume of $6.36B. Bitcoin (CBBTC) follows with a price of $91,281 (+1.3%) and a 24-hour volume of $32.08M on Solana. Ethereum (WETH) is priced at $3,136 (+0.8%) with a 24-hour volume of $29.41M. Zcash (ZEC) shows a price of $506.99 (+0.4%) and $10.67M in volume. Monad (MON) and Hyperliquid (HYPE) have volumes of $1.76M and $1.24M respectively. All assets show positive 24-hour price trends indicated by green trendlines. The interface includes tabs for Trending, Majors, DeFi, Stocks, and Cults, with the Majors tab currently active.

content.title: Cryptocurrency Market Data: Top Assets on Solana
content.description: The image displays a cryptocurrency market overview, specifically focusing on the top major assets on the Solana blockchain. The data is presented in a table format, including the rank, asset symbol, current price, market capitalization, and a 24-hour price change percentage. The top assets listed are SOL (Solana), cbBTC, WETH, ZEC, MON, and NEAR, and BNB. The image also features a "Trade" button and a star icon, suggesting trading functionality. The 24-hour price change percentages are displayed next to each asset, with some showing positive and some negative changes. The overall layout is clean and informative, providing a quick snapshot of the market performance of these assets.

content.title: Solana x402 Spotlights: Top Gainers, Most Traded, and Trending Tokens

The image is divided into three sections: Top Gainers, Most Traded, and Trending. The Top Gainers section displays the tokens with the highest percentage increases, including X4PAY (+41.6%), ACE (+30%), AVO (+29.2%), DREAMS (+28%), and HYPER (+23.9%). The Most Traded section lists tokens with their trading volumes in USD, featuring ACE ($38.25M), DREAMS ($23.99M), SWTCH ($6.89M), PAYAI ($5.21M), and CODEC ($4.04M). The Trending section showcases the tokens currently gaining attention: ACE, PAYAI, X4PAY, SWTCH, and SFY. The Solana Daily logo and social media handles are present at the bottom.

rawResponse.title: Top Solana Ecosystem Coins by Market Cap
rawResponse.text:
View all tokens and cryptocurrencies used within the Solana Ecosystem below.
Read More about Solana Ecosystem

Solana is a general purpose blockchain similar to Ethereum. The underlying architecture is different, such that developers have to write applications using Rust instead of Solidity or Vyper. However, this may soon change with the introduction of the Neon EVM solution on Solana. End user applications as of now include decentralized finance (DeFi), non-fungible tokens (NFT), marketplaces, games, and more. One of its biggest features is its scalability in which Solana is able to process over 700,000 transactions per second. Its high throughput capability appeals to high frequency traders, which is spearheaded by FTX and Alameda Research. The first use case for DeFi applications on Solana is Serum, built by the team behind FTX.Â Building in the Solana Ecosytem? Check out our [Solana Data API](https://www.coingecko.com/en/api/solana)

**Top[Solana](https://solana.org/)Projects: Titan Analytics Leaderboard Insights**
Solana has emerged as one of the leading blockchain platforms, thanks to its high throughput, low transaction costs, and a vibrant ecosystem of decentralized applications (dApps). At the heart of this ecosystem is Titan Analytics, your go-to source for data-driven insights and analytics that empower Solana users to make informed decisions. This article will delve into some of the top projects on Solana, offering insights through our robust leaderboard features.
**What is the Solana Network?**
Solana is a high-performance blockchain designed for decentralized applications and crypto projects. It boasts some impressive capabilities, including the ability to process over 65,000 transactions per second (TPS) and a unique consensus mechanism called Proof of History (PoH). These features enable Solana to be the platform of choice for developers looking to build scalable applications.
**Why Titan Analytics?**
As a Solana validator and an analytics platform, Titan Analytics brings valuable insights into the performance and growth of Solana projects. Our Leaderboard provides a comprehensive overview of the most active and engaging projects on the network, allowing you to track trends and make educated decisions.

searchParams.query: what are the top trending assets on Solana

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search results are highly relevant to the query about top trending assets on Solana. All 15 results contain information about trending tokens, top gainers, most traded assets, or hot pairs on the Solana blockchain. The results come from various cryptocurrency tracking platforms (DexScreener, DEXTools, Phantom wallet, market dashboards) and show current trending data with rankings, prices, volumes, and market caps.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The quality is strong overall. Results include specific data points (prices, market caps, trading volumes, percentage changes), come from reputable sources, and provide actionable information. Images show actual market data dashboards with clear metrics. However, some results are dated (October-December 2025/early 2026) which may not reflect current trends if the query seeks real-time data. The data appears accurate for the timestamps shown, with consistent formatting across sources.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: Most content is directly relevant, but there's moderate redundancy across results. Multiple images show similar information (top major assets lists, trending tokens rankings) with overlapping tokens appearing in different results. Some entries include peripheral information like platform UI elements, promotional banners, and social media metadata that don't directly answer the query. Approximately 25-30% of the token content is repetitive or tangential, though the core data remains useful.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The results provide a comprehensive view of trending Solana assets across multiple dimensions: major assets by market cap (SOL, cbBTC, WETH), trending memecoins and smaller tokens (PENGU, FARTCOIN, WOJAK), hot trading pairs, top gainers, and most traded tokens. Multiple timeframes are covered (1H, 24H, 7D). However, the results lack contextual information about WHY these assets are trending, fundamental analysis, or guidance on how to interpret the data. Also missing: exact query timestamp context to assess data freshness.
key_strengths: Comprehensive coverage across multiple trending categories (major assets, memecoins, hot pairs, gainers)
Specific quantitative data (prices, market caps, volumes, percentage changes) from actual trading platforms
Multiple authoritative sources (DEXTools, DexScreener, Phantom wallet, market dashboards)
Visual evidence through dashboard screenshots providing verifiable data
Coverage of different timeframes (1H, 24H, 7D, 30D) for trend analysis
Diverse asset types from established coins (SOL, BTC, ETH) to emerging tokens
key_weaknesses: Significant redundancy with similar trending lists repeated across multiple results
Dates range from October 2025 to January 2026, unclear if this represents current data relative to query time
No contextual explanation of trending factors or market dynamics
Some results include UI clutter and promotional content reducing information density
Missing synthesis or aggregation - results are raw data dumps without interpretation
No guidance on data reliability or how to use trending information for decision-making
evaluation.overall_assessment: This is a high-quality search result that effectively answers the query about top trending Solana assets. The results provide extensive, specific data from credible sources across multiple market segments and timeframes. The main strengths are comprehensiveness, data specificity, and source diversity. The primary weaknesses are redundancy across results and lack of contextual analysis. For a user seeking to understand what's trending on Solana, this provides excellent raw data but would benefit from less duplication and more synthesis. The relevant information density could be improved by 20-25% through deduplication, but the core answer quality is strong.

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search results are moderately relevant to the query about 'top trending assets on Solana'. Many results discuss Solana ecosystem tokens, memecoins, NFTs, and leaderboards. However, the query specifically asks about 'trending' assets (implying current, real-time trends), while many results provide general overviews, historical information, or incomplete data. The Solscan Token Leaderboard and CoinScan trending results are most directly relevant, but their content is truncated or lacks actual data. Several results discuss broader ecosystem topics rather than specifically trending assets.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The quality is mixed. Several results contain substantial boilerplate content (cookie policies, navigation menus, login prompts) that dilutes the actual information. Many pages are truncated mid-sentence, leaving incomplete information. Some results like the Kraken and CoinGecko pages contain mostly navigation elements with minimal substantive content. The OKX, KuCoin, and RapidInnovation articles appear more structured but still lack specific current data. The Solscan and CoinScan pages promise real-time trending data but the actual token listings are either empty or incomplete in the search results.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: The information density is poor. A significant portion of the search contents consists of irrelevant elements: cookie consent banners, navigation menus, social media links, footer information, and sign-up prompts. Many results are 30-50% boilerplate content. The Kraken result is almost entirely cookie policy text. Several results are cut off before reaching substantive content about actual trending tokens. Only a small fraction of the total text directly addresses which specific Solana assets are currently trending, with most content being general ecosystem descriptions or incomplete data tables.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The search results fail to provide a complete answer to what the top trending Solana assets currently are. While multiple sources are provided (Solscan, CoinScan, CoinGecko, CoinMarketCap), the actual trending token data is either missing, truncated, or presented as empty tables. No specific token names, prices, or ranking information is clearly presented in most results. The query asks for actionable information about trending assets, but a user would struggle to extract concrete token names or trends from this content. The results provide context about where to find such information but don't deliver the actual data.
key_strengths: Multiple authoritative sources included (CoinGecko, CoinMarketCap, Solscan, CoinScan)
Covers diverse aspects of Solana ecosystem (DeFi, NFTs, memecoins, tokens)
Includes both aggregator sites and analytics platforms
Some results mention specific project categories and use cases
Provides multiple perspectives on Solana trending assets
key_weaknesses: Excessive boilerplate content (cookie policies, navigation, footers) consuming significant token budget
Critical data tables and token listings are truncated or empty
Lack of specific, actionable information about current trending tokens
Many results cut off before reaching substantive content
Heavy redundancy across multiple similar marketplace/tracker sites
No clear, concise list of actual trending token names with current metrics
Significant portion of content is marketing copy rather than data
evaluation.overall_assessment: The search results provide a broad overview of where to find trending Solana assets but fail to deliver the specific information requested. While relevant sources are identified, the execution is poor due to excessive boilerplate content, truncated data tables, and lack of concrete trending token information. A user asking this query likely wants a straightforward list of currently trending Solana tokens with basic metrics, but would need to visit the actual websites to find this information. The search captures the right sources but doesn't extract the valuable data from them, resulting in low information density and incomplete answers. This is a mediocre result that points in the right direction but doesn't fulfill the query's intent.

content.title: Twitter thread discussing crypto assets and buyback programs
content.description: The image is a screenshot of a Twitter thread. The first tweet, by Cole, states "The asset goes up the ticker goes down lol." The second tweet, by Max Alpha, says the asset is $ETH but the ticker is $BMNR and criticizes the selling of the asset below mNAV. The third tweet, by Nasdaq Tiger, says "Start the buyback programme." The fourth tweet, by gg_eth, criticizes the company for posting the same stuff every day and claims it's a scam. The fifth tweet, by Nasdaq Tiger, asks how they are going to get the 1.5 billion for the promised buyback programme. The tweets have various engagement metrics such as replies, retweets, and likes.

content.title: Most-mentioned assets by VCs and angel investors on X
content.description: This image is a table presenting data on the most-mentioned assets by VCs and angel investors on X (formerly Twitter). The table includes the following columns: Project, Total Mentions, Mentions % Change, Unique Investors, and Investors % Change. The projects listed are Bitcoin (BTC), Solana (SOL), Ethereum (ETH), Hyperliquid (HYPE), Pump.Fun (PUMP), World Liberty Financial (WLFI), and Base Chain (BASE). The data shows the total mentions for each project, the percentage change in mentions, the number of unique investors, and the percentage change in investors. content.title: Twitter thread discussing Tether's potential asset sales
content.description: The image is a screenshot of a Twitter thread discussing the possibility of Tether selling its gold, Bitcoin, and non-treasury assets to become compliant. The first tweet, by @jason, suggests that this topic will be discussed in the next six months. The tweet also mentions that rate cuts will make the business less attractive, but going legit in 2026 is a better plan. A reply by @based16z bets $1 million on the odds that Tether won't sell all their gold and Bitcoin in the next 12 months. Another user, @btcgenesis, replies to @based16z and @Jason.

content.title: Most-mentioned assets by VCs and angel investors on X
content.description: This image is a table from the "On the Investor Radar" report, displaying the most-mentioned assets by VCs and angel investors on X (formerly Twitter). The table includes the following columns: Project, Total Mentions, Mentions % Change, Unique Investors, and Investors % Change. The data covers the following projects: Bitcoin (BTC) with 4321 total mentions, a -6.04% change in mentions, 2074 unique investors, and a -15.03% change in investors; Solana (SOL) with 3226 total mentions, a +37.69% change in mentions, 1680 unique investors, and a +26.70% change in investors; Ethereum (ETH) with 2802 total mentions, a -49.27% change in mentions, 1736 unique investors, and a -42.99% change in investors; Hyperliquid (HYPE) with 1411 total mentions, a +116.00% change in mentions, 1072 unique investors, and a +90.41% change in investors; Pump.Fun (PUMP) with 519 total mentions, a +136.65% change in mentions, 424 unique investors, and a +95.39% change in investors; World Liberty Financial (WLFI) with 473 total mentions, a +272.38% change in mentions, 304 unique investors, and a +169.03% change in investors; and Base Chain (BASE) with 396 total mentions, a -2.18% change in mentions, 342 unique investors, and a -6.30% change in investors.

content.title: Capital flowing into tokenized RWAs and institutional products
content.summary: Tweet reports real-world asset (RWA) activity: Mavryk shows a $10B real-estate pipeline and $100M FDV, Fidelity's tokenized money market (FDIT) exceeds $250M AUM. Capital is rotating into MVRK, Maple, Ondo; Ostium distributed 500k points to 1,320 traders; institutional custody flows ramping in 2025.

bullets: Mavryk cited with $10B real-estate pipeline and $100M FDV (tweet claims those figures).
Fidelity's tokenized money market (FDIT) reported above $250M AUM in the tweet.
Author says capital rotating into $MVRK, $MAPLE, $ONDO â€” names highlighted as inflows.
Ostium distribution: 500,000 points allocated across 1,320 traders per tweet.
Author forecasts institutional custody flows ramping through 2025.

content.title: Clankers are first class assets on Farcaster
content.summary: Farcaster highlights that Clankers are first class assets. Clankers are tokens that automatically show the creator. Farcaster is working on an alternate way to verify ownership for tokens that are not Clankers. Clankers are first class assets.

bullets: Clankers are tokens that automatically show the creator of the token.
Farcaster is working on an alternate way to verify ownership for tokens that are not Clankers.

Clanker token pages on Farcaster include information such as quantity, USD value, creator, market cap, age, 24H volume, liquidity, fully diluted valuation, contract address, platform, chain, and website.

content.title: Twitter thread discussing ZEC and BTC
content.description: The image is a screenshot of a Twitter thread. The first tweet, by "The Wolf Of All Streets", warns that $ZEC is being pumped through a coordinated effort, and that few people care about privacy, but want to see the number go up. The second tweet, also by "The Wolf Of All Streets", states that VanEck CEO warns $BTC may lose ground as OG investors shift toward privacy-focused $ZEC. The tweet includes the VanEck logo and the Zcash logo. A reply by mert | helius.dev discusses how people talk about a coin and how social media algorithms promote the topic. The reply concludes with the statement "welcome to how the internet works gentlemen" and the price "$10,000". The image includes the number of likes, retweets, and comments for each tweet.

content.title: MacroScope Tweet on Inflation Target and Asset Implications
content.description: The image is a screenshot of a tweet by MacroScope from October 25, 2022. The tweet states that a new inflation target is coming and that it will be tacit, with overt being a bridge too far for now. The tweet also mentions the implications for all assets, specifically mentioning bonds and Bitcoin (BTC), with the former having been "sniffing it out."

content.title: Twitter Trending Topics: Bitcoin, Arrest, Polymarket, and Theoliquid
content.description: The image is a screenshot of Twitter's trending topics. The top trend is "#Bitcoin" with 92.4K posts, categorized under "Business & finance". The second trend is "Arrest" with 134K posts, categorized under "Politics". The third trend is "Polymarket" with 59.5K posts, and the fourth is "Theoliquid". The image also includes a "Show more" button at the bottom.

content.title: Hyperliquid Lists Spot Assets
content.summary: Hyperliquid now lists three spot assets among its top 10 assets. The exchange promotes its platform as a venue where '10-figure whales' trade. Trade spot on Hyperliquid.

bullets: Three of the top 10 assets on Hyperliquid are now spot assets.
Hyperliquid promotes its platform as a venue where '10-figure whales' trade.
Users can now trade spot assets on Hyperliquid.

content.title: Tweets about gold price and currency utilization
content.description: The image is a screenshot of two tweets. The first tweet, by goodalexander, states, "look at the gold price and tell me people want dollars. not gold." The tweet has 1 reply, 2 likes, and 70 views. The second tweet, by Stablecoin Intern, states, "asset prices aren't indicative of currency utilization, fx flows are." The tweet has 1 reply, 1 like, and 35 views.

content.title: Generative Art as Real Asset; Fidenza, Sui, ETFs
content.summary: Generative art evolves into a real asset class. Fidenza spread hits 34k. Cross-chain infrastructure live on Sui. ETFs incoming. Key point: Generative art evolving.

bullets: Fidenza spread has reached 34k across different venues.
Cross-chain infrastructure is now operational on the Sui blockchain.
Exchange Traded Funds are expected to be introduced.

content.title: Twitter posts about crypto portfolio and trading
content.description: The image is a screenshot of three Twitter posts. The first post is from "Chicken Genius" who states they started drawing down their public crypto portfolio. The second post is from "Orangie" who mentions putting $200k into Robinhood to play around with tech stocks and quantum computing, and that it's up pretty good so far. The third post is from "kook" who states they have almost no interest in trading crypto anymore and that equities and equity options are much more interesting.

content.title: The Fed Boosts Solana, Solana Enters Professional Soccer & More
content.summary: The post discusses Solana's strong technical capabilities, community, and economic potential, highlighting its suitability for payments and financial inclusion, especially in Africa where mobile money services like M-Pesa have been transformative. It also covers Solana's integration into professional soccer, university curriculum, and advancements in zk-SNARK technology.

# X (Twitter)Statistics and Usage Trends
X (Formerly Twitter) is a fast-paced place for discussions. These X (Twitter) statistics can help marketers and brands better reach their audience.
## X (Twitter) Statistics: User Demographics and Numbers
X (Twitter) is one of the largest social media platforms in the world. With[over 619](https://www.demandsage.com/twitter-statistics/)million monthly active users worldwide, it is no surprise that it is also a very influential platform.
In 2023, Elon Musk bought Twitter and changed its name to X. While Twitterâ€™s acquisition was seen as a controversial move at the time, X continues to show**growth and changing trends**in its user base.
Understanding key Twitter statistics is useful for both casual Twitter users and marketers, as the social media platform is an ideal environment for businesses who want to implement a content marketing strategy.
## X (Formerly Twitter) User Statistics
This section will cover demographic and behavioral differences within X (Twitter) usage for a more comprehensive image of the platform.
Understanding general[social media statistics](https://sociallyin.com/social-media-statistics/)will provide marketers a better perspective of how X as a platform compares to other rival sites.
## Global User Base
X (Twitter) is one of the top social media platforms in the world. A large portion of Twitterâ€™s user base is active on both a daily and monthly basis, with the distribution of users differing from country to country.
## Total Number Of Active Users Worldwide
X (Twitter) has**619 million monthly active users worldwide**in 2024.
While it isnâ€™t in the[top 5](https://www.demandsage.com/twitter-statistics/)most used social media sites, it ranks among the likes of TikTok and Snapchat due to the size of its user base.

searchParams.query: what assets are being discussed on twitter

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search contents directly address the query by providing multiple data points about assets being discussed on Twitter/X. The results include specific mention counts, trending topics, and VC/investor discussions. Most content items explicitly reference Twitter discussions about various crypto assets (Bitcoin, Ethereum, Solana, Hyperliquid, etc.). Some items are tangentially related (discussing assets but not always specifically Twitter activity), but the majority is highly relevant.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The contents are well-structured with clear data tables showing mention counts, percentage changes, and investor engagement metrics. Screenshots of actual Twitter threads provide authenticity. The Messari data on most-mentioned assets by VCs is particularly high-quality with specific metrics. However, some image descriptions are repetitive (multiple similar tables about the same data), and a few items lack clear timestamps or context about when the discussions occurred.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: While most content is on-topic, there's significant redundancy with multiple results (image_id 245237, 239791) showing nearly identical data about VC mentions on X. Several Twitter thread screenshots describe similar discussions without adding new information. The post about Fidelity's tokenized assets and Clankers, while tangentially related, doesn't directly answer what's being discussed on Twitter. Approximately 30-35% of the content is redundant or only loosely connected to the query, reducing token efficiency.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The results provide a comprehensive snapshot of assets discussed on Twitter, covering major cryptocurrencies (Bitcoin, Ethereum, Solana), emerging projects (Hyperliquid, Pump.Fun, World Liberty Financial), and even niche topics (Zcash privacy, tokenized RWAs). The data includes both quantitative metrics (mention counts, percentage changes) and qualitative discussions (actual tweet threads). However, the results are somewhat crypto-focused and miss other asset classes that might be discussed on Twitter (stocks, commodities, real estate). The temporal scope is also unclear - some data appears recent while other items lack clear dating.
key_strengths: Quantitative data on asset mentions with specific numbers and percentage changes
Multiple perspectives: VC/investor mentions, trending topics, and organic Twitter discussions
Authentic screenshots of actual Twitter threads showing real conversations
Clear identification of specific assets with project names and tickers
Mix of established assets (BTC, ETH) and emerging projects
key_weaknesses: Significant redundancy with multiple results showing the same or very similar data tables
Heavy crypto bias - missing discussions of traditional assets (stocks, bonds, commodities) that are also discussed on Twitter
Unclear temporal scope - some results lack clear timestamps or context about when discussions occurred
Some tangentially related content that doesn't directly address Twitter discussions
Limited diversity in content types - mostly focused on crypto assets
evaluation.overall_assessment: This search result provides a solid answer to the query about assets being discussed on Twitter, with strong quantitative data and authentic examples. The Messari VC mention data is particularly valuable, showing specific metrics for Bitcoin, Solana, Ethereum, and emerging projects. However, the result suffers from redundancy (multiple identical data tables), crypto-heavy bias, and missed opportunities to cover broader asset discussions on Twitter. The information density could be improved by removing duplicate content and focusing on unique insights. Despite these weaknesses, the result would be useful for someone wanting to understand crypto asset discussions on Twitter, earning a good but not excellent overall score.

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The query asks 'what assets are being discussed on twitter' - seeking current real-time information about financial assets, cryptocurrencies, stocks, or other investment vehicles being talked about on the Twitter/X platform. However, the search results almost entirely return meta-information ABOUT Twitter itself (statistics, features, case studies, demographics) rather than content discussing what assets are being talked about ON Twitter. Only 2-3 results tangentially touch on relevant topics like crypto assets or real-world assets, but even these are general educational content, not showing what's currently being discussed on the platform.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The individual articles are reasonably well-written and informative for what they are - Twitter statistics, platform features, and general information about assets and crypto. The Federal Reserve and FINRA pages about assets are authoritative sources. However, they answer the wrong question entirely, making them high-quality content for a different query.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: Approximately 95% of the content is irrelevant to the query. Results about Twitter user demographics, platform statistics, Twitter's business model, case studies about Twitter as a company, and lists of Twitter features consume most of the token budget. Only fragments from 2-3 results mentioning crypto assets or real-world assets have any tangential relevance, but even these don't address what's being discussed ON Twitter. The token efficiency is extremely poor.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The search results completely fail to answer the query. There is no information about current trending assets on Twitter, no analysis of financial discussions happening on the platform, no mention of trending stock tickers, crypto tokens, or commodities being discussed. A complete answer would include real-time or recent data about asset mentions, trending financial topics, popular investment discussions, or sentiment analysis of asset-related conversations on Twitter.
key_strengths: Some results from authoritative sources (Federal Reserve, FINRA, World Economic Forum)
Information about crypto/digital assets provides minimal tangential relevance
Articles are generally well-structured and grammatically correct
key_weaknesses: Fundamental misinterpretation of the query - returns meta-information about Twitter rather than content discussed on Twitter
No real-time or current data about asset discussions on the platform
Massive information waste with 95%+ irrelevant content about Twitter statistics and features
Missing any actual Twitter posts, trending topics, or asset sentiment data
No mention of specific assets, tickers, cryptocurrencies, or investment vehicles being discussed
Search appears to have interpreted 'on twitter' as 'about twitter'
evaluation.overall_assessment: This search result represents a critical failure to understand and answer the user's query. The user wants to know what financial assets people are talking about on Twitter - likely seeking trending stocks, crypto tokens, or investment discussions. Instead, the search returned extensive information about Twitter as a platform (user statistics, features, demographics). This is a fundamental query interpretation error. The relevant information density is abysmal at ~1%, wasting nearly all tokens on off-topic content. The search system appears to have taken 'twitter' as the primary search term rather than understanding it as the platform where discussions are happening. A useful result would show actual Twitter trends, popular asset tickers, sentiment analysis, or aggregated discussion topics - none of which appear here.

The projects listed are: B3, Super Champs, Metacade, Uptopia, Heist by Uptopia, BRACKY, Eggle Energy, Gochujangcoin, Pett AI, Pepper, TRUE, Nanon Network, Native, thosmur, Penguins, and HEIST COIN. The image includes the text "TRENDING BASE GAMING LAST 7D" at the top. The source is cited as Geckoterminal, and the update date is Nov 29th, 2025. The image also includes the "GAMING ON BASE" logo at the bottom left and the Twitter handle "@GamingOnBase" at the bottom right.

content.title: Baselana: Base ecosystem roundup
content.summary: Base ecosystem momentum: Base hits daily transaction ATHs (16.1M), JP Morgan USD deposit token (JPMD) and major bridges (Baseâ€“Solana via Chainlink CCIP) go live, and Coinbase offers security reviews for Base builders. Multiple miniâ€‘apps and products launched or integrated into the Base App (Wasabi, Arcadia, Kaito, Limitless, Frame, Glider, 0xPPL, Remix, Slice, Towns, HYTOPIA, Upshot, Sandbox, Bantr, Bantr Rewind). Base App adds miniâ€‘app screenshots and developer testing improvements. Large developer activity: 725 Base Batch applicants, 50 finalists; hackathons and partnerships with OpenAI/Anthropic/Replit. Overall theme: product-led ecosystem growth and onchain commerce expansion.

bullets: Base recorded a new daily transaction ATH of 16.1M.
JPMorgan USD deposit token (JPMD) is live on Base for institutional transfers.
Baseâ€“Solana bridge launched, secured by Chainlink CCIP with Coinbase participation.
Multiple miniâ€‘apps now live in the Base App: Wasabi, Arcadia, Kaito, Limitless, Frame, Glider, Remix, Upshot, Sandbox.
Miniâ€‘app features: trading with leverage, automated concentrated liquidity, attention/tokenized intel, prediction markets, portfolio automation.
Base App added screenshot support for miniâ€‘apps and improved developer testing via Developer Mode toggle.
725 projects applied to Base Batches; 50 finalists to pitch at EFDevcon Demo Day.
Coinbase security team offering free beta security reviews for Base builders.
Hackathon hosted with YC, OpenAI, Anthropic, Replit, and PayWithLocus â€” developer onboarding focus.
Onchain commerce growth highlighted: Slice, Slash, Thx App, Base Pay integrations and cashback/card products.
Creator economy and writer coins (Paragraph), gaming (HYTOPIA, Remix) and fantasy/arena products launching on Base.
Payments UX improvements: buy tokens via a like, Apple Pay onramp for BTC (Thx App).
Base positioned as the hub for an 'everything' economy and creator capital markets.
Emphasis on builders shipping despite market conditions; community and product momentum framed as durable growth.
Ecosystem narrative ties to institutional adoption, bridges, tooling, and growing consumer experiences.

content.title: Xora on Base: Coin Tweets on-chain
content.description: The image is a screenshot of a Twitter feed featuring three posts. The first post, by mattlee, introduces "Base Tones," explaining that they are onchain and represent tones between 20 and 20000 Hz. The second post, by saarim not sorry, mentions something new is coming to help creators on @base. The third post, by anku, announces Xora's launch on @farcaster_xyz and its upcoming availability on Base, allowing users to coin their tweets. The image also includes a promotional graphic for Xora, inviting users to "Coin your best tweets on-chain" and offering options to connect, import Twitter archives, pick tweets, or create coins.

ðŸ—£ï¸ As the week concludes, the coins getting the highest increases in discussion are being dominated by top caps:

ðŸª™ Bitcoin $BTC: The word 'bitcoin' is trending due to extensive discussions about its investment potential, market behavior, adoption stages, and comparison with gold. It is highlighted for its scarcity, utility, and role as a digital monetary network, with emphasis on long-term holding strategies, market timing advice, and evolving government and institutional involvement. Debates focus on bitcoin's value drivers, use cases beyond store of value, and the importance of self-custody and running nodes for security and sovereignty. Additionally, 'btc' is trending for its frequent mention in transferable and spendable flash cryptocurrency offers involving BTC and USDT, promoting its liquidity, usability in trading, gaming, and betting sites, and availability for instant delivery and trading.

ðŸª™ Ethereum $ETH: The word 'eth' is trending because it appears frequently in texts related to transferable and spendable crypto flash tokens, including Ethereum (ETH) alongside other cryptocurrencies like BTC and USDT. The texts promote flash tokens usable on multiple wallets and platforms, emphasizing their transferability, spendability, and trading features. 'Eth' is mentioned as part of crypto flash offerings and investment opportunities, indicating its relevance in the crypto finance context.

ðŸª™ Microstrategy $MSTR: The word 'mstr' is trending due to discussions about MicroStrategy, a company known for holding large Bitcoin reserves and acting as a leveraged proxy for Bitcoin exposure. Key topics include debates on holding MSTR shares versus ETFs, the potential impact of MicroStrategy's inclusion in the S&P 500 index, and the resulting market effects such as institutional buying and passive fund inflows.

searchParams.query: what Base assets are trending on twitter

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search contents directly address the query by providing multiple sources showing Base assets trending on Twitter/X. The results include specific trending token lists with performance metrics, social media posts from Base ecosystem accounts, and visual snapshots of trending assets. However, the query asks specifically about 'what is trending on Twitter' and while many results are Twitter posts, some content (like Paragraph articles and Clanker pages) are not strictly Twitter content, slightly reducing perfect alignment.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The contents are generally high quality with clear structure, specific data points (token names, percentage gains, market caps), and verifiable sources. Posts include proper attribution, dates, and links. The information is presented with good organization through summaries and key points. However, some results are dated (oldest from July 2025, query appears to be from early 2026), and there's some inconsistency in the level of detail across different results. The mix of recent and older trending data could confuse temporal context.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: Most content directly addresses trending Base assets, but there's notable noise. Result #4 (image about general Twitter trending topics with Bitcoin, Arrest, Polymarket) is irrelevant to Base assets. Several results include extensive metadata about projects, bridges, and ecosystem developments that, while Base-related, don't directly answer 'what's trending.' The Baselana ecosystem roundup is comprehensive but sprawling with details about mini-apps and partnerships that dilute the core trending assets information. Approximately 70-75% of content is directly relevant.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The search provides a reasonably complete picture of trending Base assets with multiple data points: memecoin trends (Brett, Keyboard Cat, doginme), top gainers over different timeframes (24h, 7d), specific tokens with performance metrics, and visual representations. It covers different categories (memes, gaming, general tokens) and multiple time periods. However, it lacks a single consolidated current snapshot and doesn't provide clear explanations of WHY certain assets are trending (news catalysts, narratives). The temporal spread of data (July 2025 - January 2026) means it's not a singular 'current' trending list.
key_strengths: Provides specific token names, tickers, and quantitative performance data (percentage gains, market caps)
Multiple independent sources and perspectives (Jesse Pollak, Base Insights, community accounts)
Includes visual evidence through screenshots of trending lists
Covers different timeframes and categories of trending assets
Recent and timely data from the Base ecosystem
Clear attribution and verifiable source links
key_weaknesses: Contains at least one completely irrelevant result (general Twitter trending topics unrelated to Base)
Temporal inconsistency - mix of data from July 2025 through January 2026 without clear current snapshot
Some results are ecosystem news rather than trending asset lists
Lack of explanation for WHY assets are trending (catalysts, narratives, news)
Redundancy across multiple trending lists without clear differentiation of timeframes
Heavy metadata about projects that doesn't directly answer the trending question
evaluation.overall_assessment: This is a solid search result that successfully identifies trending Base assets from Twitter/social sources with concrete data. The strength lies in providing multiple specific trending lists with performance metrics and visual evidence. However, the result suffers from inclusion of irrelevant content, temporal inconsistency across results, and information density issues where ecosystem news dilutes the core trending assets information. For a user asking 'what Base assets are trending,' they would find useful answers but would need to filter through noise and reconcile different timeframes. The result would benefit from tighter relevance filtering and clearer temporal organization.

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The query asks specifically about 'Base assets trending on twitter' - referring to cryptocurrency assets on the Base blockchain that are trending on Twitter/X. Most search results provide generic trending crypto information, Twitter trending tools, or general tokenization content. Only 2-3 results (GeckoTerminal Base pools, Raster Trends) actually relate to Base blockchain assets, but even these don't specifically address Twitter trending data for Base assets. The search largely missed the mark on understanding 'Base' as a specific blockchain network.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The individual search results are moderately quality sources - they include legitimate crypto tracking sites (CoinGecko, GeckoTerminal, Messari, Santiment) and provide structured data about trending cryptocurrencies. However, there's significant duplication (multiple generic trending coin lists), incomplete content (many results are truncated navigation menus or partial tables), and the Twitter Trending Archive result is essentially useless. The technical quality of sources is decent, but presentation and completeness within each result is inconsistent.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: Approximately 85-90% of the content is irrelevant to the specific query. Results include: generic Twitter trending archives unrelated to crypto, general cryptocurrency trending lists without Base-specific filtering, tokenization influencer lists, a 2022 article about NFTs on Twitter, navigation menus, and incomplete table structures. Only the GeckoTerminal Base pools result (~10% of total content) directly addresses Base blockchain assets, though it still doesn't specifically connect to Twitter trending data. Massive token waste with very low signal-to-noise ratio.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The search results fail to answer the core query. A complete answer would identify specific Base blockchain tokens/assets that are currently trending on Twitter, potentially with metrics like mention volume, sentiment, or trending hashtags. Instead, we get: no Base-specific Twitter trend data, no connection between Base assets and Twitter discussions, generic crypto trending lists from various platforms, and unrelated content about tokenization and Twitter tools. The one Base-relevant result (GeckoTerminal) shows trading pools but provides no Twitter trending information.
key_strengths: Includes some authoritative crypto data sources (CoinGecko, GeckoTerminal, Santiment, Messari)
GeckoTerminal result does specifically show Base blockchain pools and trading data
Multiple perspectives on crypto trending from different platforms
Some results provide structured data formats (tables, rankings)
key_weaknesses: Fundamental misunderstanding of 'Base' as a specific blockchain network
No integration between Base assets and Twitter trending data
Excessive irrelevant content (80-90% noise)
Multiple duplicate or near-duplicate results about generic trending coins
Incomplete content with truncated tables and navigation elements
2-year-old article about general crypto on Twitter
Generic Twitter trending tool with no crypto focus
Tokenization influencer list completely off-topic
No actionable data connecting Base ecosystem tokens to Twitter discussions
evaluation.overall_assessment: This search result represents a significant failure to understand and address the query. The user asked for a specific intersection of data: assets on the Base blockchain that are trending on Twitter. The search system appears to have treated these as separate concepts, returning generic crypto trending data and Twitter tools without connecting them. While a few results touch on Base blockchain data, none provide Twitter trending analysis for Base assets. The information density is extremely poor with massive token waste on irrelevant content. To be useful, this search would need Base-specific social media monitoring, Twitter mention tracking for Base ecosystem tokens, or at minimum, filtered trending lists showing only Base chain assets. As delivered, this would require the user to manually cross-reference multiple incomplete sources to extract any useful information.

question.query: how does solana turbine block propagation work

content.title: Turbine: Block Propagation on Solana
content.summary: Turbine is Solana's innovative block propagation mechanism that breaks blocks into smaller shreds and disseminates them through a structured hierarchy of nodes. This optimizes bandwidth usage and ensures fast, reliable data availability across the network. Turbine leverages erasure coding and a dynamic Turbine Tree to mitigate packet loss and enable high throughput. Compared to Ethereum's gossip-based propagation, Solana's Turbine stands out with its higher bandwidth requirements, UDP-based transmission, and dynamic tree structure.

content.title: Turbine: Block Propagation on Solana
content.summary: Article analyzes Turbine, Solana's block propagation mechanism, ensuring data availability and network efficiency. Turbine breaks blocks into shreds, uses erasure coding for data protection, and propagates data via a Turbine Tree. Solana uses UDP, Ethereum uses TCP. Key point: Turbine optimizes data propagation from leader to network.

bullets: Turbine is designed to mitigate the stress of egress (sending data out) from the leader to the network.
It breaks a block down into smaller pieces and disseminates these pieces through a hierarchy of nodes.
Erasure coding is used as a data protection method so that the original data can be recovered even if some parts are lost or corrupted during transmission.
Leaders can dynamically adjust the FEC rate based on network conditions.
A Turbine Tree is a structured network topology used by Solana to facilitate the efficient propagation of shreds among validators.
The Turbine Tree is typically a 2- or 3-hop tree, given the current DATA_PLANE_FANOUT value of 200.

content.title: Solana Turbine Block Propagation Diagram
content.description: The image is a diagram illustrating Solana's block propagation method, Turbine. At the top, the "Solana Leader" node is depicted, sending data to a "Root Node." The Root Node then distributes data to three "Validator" nodes (Validator 1, Validator 2, and Validator 3). These validators further propagate the data to other validators (Validator 4 through Validator 12). The diagram shows "Erasure-coded chunks" being distributed. The "Turbine" logo is present, indicating the block propagation method. The diagram visualizes the tree-like structure of data propagation in Solana's Turbine.

content.title: Solana: Faster Transaction Observation
content.summary: Solana's blocktimes are technically 400ms, but developers can achieve faster speeds using Helius shreds, enabling transaction observation in about 70ms.

bullets: Solana's technical blocktimes are 400ms, but faster speeds are achievable for developers.
Helius shreds enable transaction observation in about 70ms end-to-end latency on median.
A form is provided for searchers interested in gaining an edge.

content.title: Solana Shreds and Latency in Decentralized Systems
content.summary: Toly comments on Solana's shred propagation and Helius' LaserStream, noting decentralization enhances reliability without inherent speed drawbacks. Helius uses high stake to provide faster data via LaserStream. Solana divides blocks into shreds for faster propagation.

bullets: Solana divides blocks into shreds, which are smaller packets, for faster data propagation across the network.
Shreds allow for early access to on-chain state changes, crucial for latency-sensitive applications.
LaserStream is Heliusâ€™ gRPC streaming service that uses low-latency shreds to provide faster data streaming.
It offers multi-source ingestion, global coverage, and historical replay capabilities.
Validators with higher stake receive shreds sooner due to stake-weighted shuffling in Turbine.
Helius, with the highest stake on Solana, ensures its customers receive data the fastest.

content.title: Helius' LaserStream for Ultra-Low Latency on Solana
content.summary: Helius highlights LaserStream, a gRPC streaming service that outperforms other data-streaming services globally without requiring dedicated nodes. LaserStream provides early visibility into Solana state updates. LaserStream combines shred-level ingestion with global reach. LaserStream for Solana.

bullets: LaserStream is Heliusâ€™ next-generation gRPC streaming service.
It consistently outperforms other data-streaming services across all regions without the burden of needing to maintain dedicated nodes.
LaserStream receives propagated block data as soon as it becomes available, giving users earlier visibility into Solana state updates.
This is crucial for the detection of on-chain events and submitting transactions that react to those events.
LaserStream combines the speed of shred-level ingestion with the reliability and reach of a globally distributed service.
It eliminates the cost or operational headache of running multiple dedicated nodes.

content.title: Helius: Winning the Millisecond Game on Solana
content.summary: Helius' LaserStream is a gRPC streaming service that outperforms other data-streaming services by building upon low-latency shreds. Solana divides blocks into smaller packets called shreds, which are the atomic units of data propagation. LaserStream combines speed and reliability.

bullets: Shreds are the foundational unit that enables Solanaâ€™s high-performance data propagation, offering early access to on-chain state changes.
Blocks are divided into smaller packets known as shreds, which represent portions of transaction data before they are assembled into a block.
There are two types of shreds: Data Shreds and Coding Shreds.
The leader transmits shreds to a root node, which distributes them to subsequent layers of validators in a tree-like structure.
Each layer forwards to the next with a fanout of 200 nodes per layer, typically spanning 2 to 3 hops depending on the number of active validators.
Validators with higher stake are placed earlier in this list, and after a deterministic shuffle, they tend to end up in earlier layers of the tree closer to the leader.
LaserStream combines the speed of shred-level ingestion with the reliability and reach of a globally distributed service, without the cost or operational headache of running multiple dedicated nodes.
LaserStream ingests the lowest latency shreds, consistently beating competitors worldwide.
LaserStream is a drop-in replacement for Yellowstone gRPC.

content.title: Optimum: RLNC for Faster Consensus
content.summary: Optimum details how RLNC is the fastest and most efficient way to reach consensus, minimizing data loss. Testing against Gossipsub showed 2-20x latency improvements. Next step is Hoodi testnet.

bullets: RLNC encodes data into smaller shards using random math equations, making the original data rebuildable with any combination of shards.
RLNC enables new shard generation as data travels across the network, preventing cumulative data loss.
Each shard can be sent out to the next node as soon as it reaches a node, speeding up data flow.
Ethereum is not currently using erasure coding, and stands to benefit immensely from RLNC.
Testing against Gossipsub (standard Ethereum propagation) showed 2-20x latency improvements at various block sizes.
Optimum is setting up node operator partners with OptimumP2P.
The next step in RLNC's path to Ethereum mainnet is Hoodi testnet.

content.title: Solana Multi-Leader Turbine Diagram
content.description: The image is a diagram illustrating the Solana Multi-Leader Turbine, specifically focusing on the process of broadcasting a packed block to all validators. The diagram features three leaders (Leader 1, Leader 2, and Leader 3), each represented by an oval shape and connected to six red nodes (R1 to R6). Each leader has six blocks labeled L1-1 to L1-6, L2-1 to L2-6, and L3-1 to L3-6 respectively. The red nodes are connected to a central 'Consensus Leader' node, which is purple. The Consensus Leader then connects to four validators (V1 to V4), represented by blue ovals. The diagram shows the flow of information with arrows indicating the connections between leaders, red nodes, the consensus leader, and validators. The packed block is shown in a blue rectangle below the Consensus Leader, containing data from each leader's blocks. The diagram also includes 'IHAVE' labels on the lines connecting the red nodes to the Consensus Leader, indicating the data transfer process. The diagram is a visual representation of the Solana Turbine's block propagation mechanism.

content.title: Comparison of Block Propagation Methods: RaptorCast, Turbine, and Celestia's Approach
content.description: The image is a diagram comparing three block propagation methods: Monad's RaptorCast, Solana's Turbine, and Celestia's approach. The Monad Leader sends data to RaptorCast, which then distributes erasure-coded chunks to validators, who rebroadcast them. Solana Leader uses Turbine to send data to a Root Node, which then distributes erasure-coded chunks to validators. Validators then send data to other validators. Celestia Leader sends data to validators, with Validator 3 sending data to Validator n. The diagram illustrates the different data distribution and propagation strategies employed by each blockchain or protocol. The diagram also shows the use of erasure coding for data availability.

content.title: Solana Turbine and RaptorCast Data Propagation Diagrams
content.description: The image presents two diagrams illustrating data propagation methods. The first diagram, labeled "Solana Leader," depicts a data flow starting from a "Solana Leader" node, which sends data to a "Root Node." The Root Node then distributes data to "Validator 1," "Validator 2," and "Validator 3." Each validator further propagates the data to multiple other validators (Validator 4 through 12). The process involves "Erasure-coded chunks" at the Root Node. The second diagram, labeled "Leader N," shows a similar process using "RaptorCast." Data originates from "Leader N" and is sent to "RaptorCast," which then distributes it to "Validator 1," "Validator 2," and "Validator n." These validators then "Rebroadcast" the data to other validators (Validator 1, 2, and n). Erasure-coded chunks are also present in this diagram. The diagrams visually represent data distribution and redundancy strategies in a blockchain network, highlighting the use of erasure coding for data availability.

content.title: Solana's Rotor: New Block Propagation Protocol
content.summary: Anza details Rotor, Solana's new block propagation protocol introduced in the Alpenglow upgrade. Rotor replaces Turbine, delivering blocks faster and more uniformly, boosting throughput and reducing fork risks. Rotor improves block times.

bullets: Rotor is Solanaâ€™s new block propagation protocol introduced in the Alpenglow upgrade.
It replaces Turbineâ€™s multi-hop system with a single layer of relayers.
The leader pipelines a block into slices, erasure-codes each slice into shreds, then sends each shred to a selected relayer.
Relayers broadcast their shred to all validators globally in a single round.
Rotor cuts down propagation time and variability, ensuring nearly all validators receive the block simultaneously.
This boosts throughput and reduces the risk of forks caused by slow block delivery or network lag.

content.title: Solana's Alpenglow Upgrade Details
content.summary: Ray notes the irony of Alpenglow starting at ETH Zurich. The quoted tweet details Solana's Alpenglow upgrade, which aims to simplify consensus, improve finality to ~150ms, and introduce offchain voting.

bullets: Aims to simplify Solana consensus by removing existing baggage.
Targets finality in roughly 150ms, a 100x improvement.
Introduces Votor, where voting coordination happens offchain.
Validators don't have to sign every slot, reducing voting transactions.
Promises cheaper validator operations, with estimates claiming up to 80% reduction.
Introduces a '20+20' security model, tolerating 20% offline and 20% malicious nodes.
Faster finality eliminates ambiguity around 'confirmed' or 'finalized'.
Developers need to support the shift to push channels and certificate subscriptions.
MEV rewards may see chunky cuts, and shorter grace periods could drive stake concentration.

# Turbine Block Propagation
A Solana cluster uses a multi-layer block propagation mechanism called*Turbine*to broadcast ledger entries to all nodes. The cluster divides itself into layers
of nodes, and each node in a given layer is responsible for propagating any data
it receives on to a small set of nodes in the next downstream layer. This way
each node only has to communicate with a small number of nodes.
## Layer Structure[â€‹](#layer-structure)
The leader communicates with a special root node. The root can be thought of as
layer 0 and communicates with layer 1, which is made up of at most`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes. If the number of nodes in the cluster is greater than
layer 1, then the data plane fanout mechanism adds layers below. The number of
nodes in each additional layer grows by a factor of`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`.
A good way to think about this is, layer 0 starts with a single node, layer 1
starts with fanout nodes, and layer 2 will have`fanout \* number of nodes in
layer 1`and so on.
### Layer Assignment - Weighted Selection[â€‹](#layer-assignment----weighted-selection)
In order for data plane fanout to work, the entire cluster must agree on how the
cluster is divided into layers. To achieve this, all the recognized validator
nodes(the TVU peers)are shuffled with a stake weighting and stored in a
list. This list is then indexed in different ways to figure out layer boundaries
and retransmit peers - referred to as the(turbine tree). For example, the
list is shuffled and leader selects the first node to be the root node, and the
root node selects the next`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes to make up layer 1. The
shuffle is biased towards higher staked nodes, allowing heavier votes to come
back to the leader first. Layer 2 and lower-layer nodes use the same logic to
find their next layer peers.
To reduce the possibility of attack vectors, the list is shuffl

rawResponse.title: Turbine - Solana Handbook
rawResponse.author: Ackee Blockchain Security
rawResponse.text:
Turbine
# Turbine
Turbine is a block propagation protocol designed to reduce both time needed for block propagation as well as the overall message complexity, reducing the communication overhead of a node.
Nodes in the network are divided into small partitions called**neighborhoods**. Nodes within a particular neighborhood are responsible for sharing received data with other nodes in the same neighborhood and propagating the data to a small number of nodes in other neighborhoods.
![Blockchain](../../images/neighbours2.png)![Blockchain](../../images/neighbours.png)
Info
The data unit shared is called a**shred**, and each block is composed of many shreds.
## Problems with Broadcasting
Since we are in an adversarial environment, any node can decide not to rebroadcast the received shreds or broadcast incorrect data.
Countermeasures:
* **Erasure Codes**help by broadcasting a block with more shreds than necessary to reconstruct the entire block without errors, even if some shreds are lost along the way. With 6 data shreds and 3 additional redundant shreds, we can lose up to 1/3 of the shreds and still be able to reconstruct the entire block fully.
* A**stake-weighted selection algorithm**is used to create a tree where the risk of faulty or malicious nodes is minimized. Validators with the highest stake are positioned closer to the current leader.
July 12, 2025
Back to top

# Introduction
In traditional blockchains, block propagation occurs through a peer-to-peer network in which new blocks and transactions are broadcast to all propagating nodes. This process usually happens sequentially or is flooded. However, this method is not scalable, as it becomes difficult to manage as the network grows due to the sheer number of communications.
Letâ€™s consider a network of 35,000 validators. The leader needs to transmit a 128 MB block (about 500,000 transactions at 250 bytes per transaction) to all 35,000 validators. The traditional block propagation implementation would require the leader to have a unique connection to each validator and transmit the full 128 MB 35,000 times. This would result in a total data transmission of 4.69 TB, which is far beyond typical bandwidth capabilities and would be infeasible to accommodate with so many connections.
To solve the issue of slow block dissemination, Solana introduced Turbine, a multi-layer block propagation mechanism used by clusters to broadcast ledger entries to all nodes. Broadly speaking, Turbine breaks blocks into smaller blocks and disseminates them through an order of nodes, reducing the load on an individual nod

# Solana’s Turbine: Revolutionizing Blockchain Data Propagation
July 12, 2023 6:14 pm
[BlockChain](https://astconsulting.in/category/blockchain),[Solana](https://astconsulting.in/category/blockchain/solana)
Blockchain technology has rapidly emerged as a disruptive and revolutionary phenomenon in various sectors, providing unparalleled advantages in terms of transparency, security, and decentralized approaches.. However, the scalability and efficiency of blockchain networks have been persistent challenges. Solana, a high-performance blockchain platform, aims to address these challenges with its innovative data propagation solution, Turbine. In this article, we delve into the details of Turbine and explore how it revolutionizes blockchain data propagation.
![Solana's Turbine: Revolutionizing Blockchain Data Propagation](https://astconsulting.in/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Canva-designs-2023-07-12T154830.496.jpg)## Understanding Blockchain Data Propagation
Blockchain data propagation refers to the process of transmitting data across the network of nodes that validate and maintain the blockchain. In traditional blockchain networks, this process faces several challenges and limitations. Firstly, the speed of data propagation is often slow, leading to network congestion and increased confirmation times. Secondly, as transaction volumes increase, traditional networks struggle to handle the increased load efficiently. These challenges hinder scalability and decentralization, essential aspects of blockchain technology.
## Introducing Solana Blockchain

# Turbine: Block Propagation on Solana
![Ryan Chern](https://www.helius.dev/_next/image?url=%2Fapi%2Fmedia%2Ffile%2Fryanchern-author-image.jpg&w=96&q=90)
Ryan Chern
13min read
October 24, 2023
### Table of Contents
## [What is this article about?](#what-is-this-article-about)
Data availability is crucial to blockchains. It ensures that all necessary information is readily accessible to nodes for validation purposes, which maintains the integrity and security of the network. However, ensuring data availability while maintaining a high level of performance is a significant challenge, especially as networks scale.
Solana has risen to this challenge with a unique architectural design that facilitates continuous block creation and propagation. This is made possible through several key innovations such as leader selection, Gulf Stream (eliminates the need for a mempool), and Turbine (block propagation mechanism).
The continuous nature of Solana necessitates an efficient system to ensure that all validators receive the most updated state promptly. A simplistic approach would have the leader transmit all blocks directly to every other validator. Yet, given Solanaâ€™s high throughput, this method would significantly bloat bandwidth and other resource requirements while undermining decentralization.
Bandwidth is a scarce resource, and Turbine is Solanaâ€™s ingenious solution to optimize information propagation from the leader of a given block to the rest of the network.**Turbine was specifically designed to mitigate the stress of egress (sending data out) from the leader to the network**.
In this article, weâ€™ll dive into how Turbine works as well as its pivotal role in Solanaâ€™s broader landscape of transaction inclusion. Weâ€™ll also compare Turbine to other d

# What is Block Propagation?
A comprehensive, fact-checked guide to how new blocks travel across blockchain networks, why propagation speed matters for security and DeFi, and how leading chains optimize it.

![What is Block Propagation? A comprehensive, fact-checked guide to how new blocks travel across blockchain networks, why propagation speed matters for security and DeFi, and how leading chains optimize it.](https://www.cube.exchange/_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fcdn.sanity.io%2Fimages%2Ffegzy4pk%2Fproduction%2F1c07799cb1ca560d524868a2319f28d0cce2391c-1536x1024.png%3Fsat%3D-100&w=3840&q=75 "What is Block Propagation? A comprehensive, fact-checked guide to how new blocks travel across blockchain networks, why propagation speed matters for security and DeFi, and how leading chains optimize it.")
## Introduction
If you have ever asked what is Block Propagation and why it matters, you are already close to understanding a core performance and security factor in every public blockchain. Block propagation is the process by which a newly produced block travels across a peer-to-peer network so that honest nodes converge on the same chain view quickly. The speed, reliability, and consistency of propagation shape user experience, validator incentives, decentralized finance (DeFi) safety, and even the revenue of miners and stakers across networks like[Bitcoin (BTC)](https://www.cube.exchange/what-is/bitcoin)and[Ethereum (ETH)](https://www.cube.exchange/what-is/ethereum). Faster propagation reduces the chance of temporary forks,

# Turbine Block Propagation
A Solana cluster uses a multi-layer block propagation mechanism called*Turbine*to broadcast ledger entries to all nodes. The cluster divides itself into layers
of nodes, and each node in a given layer is responsible for propagating any data
it receives on to a small set of nodes in the next downstream layer. This way
each node only has to communicate with a small number of nodes.
## Layer Structure[â€‹](#layer-structure)
The leader communicates with a special root node. The root can be thought of as
layer 0 and communicates with layer 1, which is made up of at most`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes. If the number of nodes in the cluster is greater than
layer 1, then the data plane fanout mechanism adds layers below. The number of
nodes in each additional layer grows by a factor of`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`.
A good way to think about this is, layer 0 starts with a single node, layer 1
starts with fanout nodes, and layer 2 will have`fanout \* number of nodes in
layer 1`and so on.
### Layer Assignment - Weighted Selection[â€‹](#layer-assignment----weighted-selection)
In order for data plane fanout to work, the entire cluster must agree on how the
cluster is divided into layers. To achieve this, all the recognized validator
nodes(the TVU peers)are shuffled with a stake weighting and stored in a
list. This list is then indexed in different ways to figure out layer boundaries
and retransmit peers - referred to as the(turbine tree). For example, the
list is shuffled and leader selects the first node to be the root node, and the
root node selects the next`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes to make up layer 1. The
shuffle is biased towards higher staked nodes, allowing heavier votes to come
back to the leader first. Layer 2 and lower-layer nodes use the same logic to
find their next layer peers.
To reduce the possibility of attack vectors, the list is shuffl"

# Turbine
Turbine is a block propagation protocol designed to reduce both time needed for block propagation as well as the overall message complexity, reducing the communication overhead of a node.
Nodes in the network are divided into small partitions called**neighborhoods**. Nodes within a particular neighborhood are responsible for sharing received data with other nodes in the same neighborhood and propagating the data to a small number of nodes in other neighborhoods.
![Blockchain](../../images/neighbours2.png)![Blockchain](../../images/neighbours.png)
Info
The data unit shared is called a**shred**, and each block is composed of many shreds.
## Problems with Broadcasting
Since we are in an adversarial environment, any node can decide not to rebroadcast the received shreds or broadcast incorrect data.
Countermeasures:
* **Erasure Codes**help by broadcasting a block with more shreds than necessary to reconstruct the entire block without errors, even if some shreds are lost along the way. With 6 data shreds and 3 additional redundant shreds, we can lose up to 1/3 of the shreds and still be able to reconstruct the entire block fully.
* A**stake-weighted selection algorithm**is used to create a tree where the risk of faulty or malicious nodes is minimized. Validators with the highest stake are positioned closer to the current leader.

# Introduction
In traditional blockchains, block propagation occurs through a peer-to-peer network in which new blocks and transactions are broadcast to all propagating nodes. This process usually happens sequentially or is flooded. However, this method is not scalable, as it becomes difficult to manage as the network grows due to the sheer number of communications.
Letâ€™s consider a network of 35,000 validators. The leader needs to transmit a 128 MB block (about 500,000 transactions at 250 bytes per transaction) to all 35,000 validators. The traditional block propagation implementation would require the leader to have a unique connection to each validator and transmit the full 128 MB 35,000 times. This would result in a total data transmission of 4.69 TB, which is far beyond typical bandwidth capabilities and would be infeasible to accommodate with so many connections.
To solve the issue of slow block dissemination, Solana introduced Turbine, a multi-layer block propagation mechanism used by clusters to broadcast ledger entries to all nodes. Broadly speaking, Turbine breaks blocks into smaller blocks and disseminates them through an order of nodes, reducing the load on an individual nod"

# Turbine Block Propagation
A Solana cluster uses a multi-layer block propagation mechanism called*Turbine*to broadcast ledger entries to all nodes. The cluster divides itself into layers
of nodes, and each node in a given layer is responsible for propagating any data
it receives on to a small set of nodes in the next downstream layer. This way
each node only has to communicate with a small number of nodes.
## Layer Structure[â€‹](#layer-structure)
The leader communicates with a special root node. The root can be thought of as
layer 0 and communicates with layer 1, which is made up of at most`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes. If the number of nodes in the cluster is greater than
layer 1, then the data plane fanout mechanism adds layers below. The number of
nodes in each additional layer grows by a factor of`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`.
A good way to think about this is, layer 0 starts with a single node, layer 1
starts with fanout nodes, and layer 2 will have`fanout \* number of nodes in
layer 1`and so on.
### Layer Assignment - Weighted Selection[â€‹](#layer-assignment----weighted-selection)
In order for data plane fanout to work, the entire cluster must agree on how the
cluster is divided into layers. To achieve this, all the recognized validator
nodes(the TVU peers)are shuffled with a stake weighting and stored in a
list. This list is then indexed in different ways to figure out layer boundaries
and retransmit peers - referred to as the(turbine tree). For example, the
list is shuffled and leader selects the first node to be the root node, and the
root node selects the next`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes to make up layer 1. The
shuffle is biased towards higher staked nodes, allowing heavier votes to come
back to the leader first. Layer 2 and lower-layer nodes use the same logic to
find their next layer peers.
To reduce the possibility of attack vectors, the list is shuffled and in"

## [What is this article about?](#what-is-this-article-about)
Data availability is crucial to blockchains. It ensures that all necessary information is readily accessible to nodes for validation purposes, which maintains the integrity and security of the network. However, ensuring data availability while maintaining a high level of performance is a significant challenge, especially as networks scale.
Solana has risen to this challenge with a unique architectural design that facilitates continuous block creation and propagation. This is made possible through several key innovations such as leader selection, Gulf Stream (eliminates the need for a mempool), and Turbine (block propagation mechanism).
The continuous nature of Solana necessitates an efficient system to ensure that all validators receive the most updated state promptly. A simplistic approach would have the leader transmit all blocks directly to every other validator. Yet, given Solanaâ€™s high throughput, this method would significantly bloat bandwidth and other resource requirements while undermining decentralization.
Bandwidth is a scarce resource, and Turbine is Solanaâ€™s ingenious solution to optimize information propagation from the leader of a given block to the rest of the network.**Turbine was specifically designed to mitigate the stress of egress (sending data out) from the leader to the network**.

## Introduction
If you have ever asked what is Block Propagation and why it matters, you are already close to understanding a core performance and security factor in every public blockchain. Block propagation is the process by which a newly produced block travels across a peer-to-peer network so that honest nodes converge on the same chain view quickly. The speed, reliability, and consistency of propagation shape user experience, validator incentives, decentralized finance (DeFi) safety, and even the revenue of miners and stakers across networks like[Bitcoin (BTC)](https://www.cube.exchange/what-is/bitcoin)and[Ethereum (ETH)](https://www.cube.exchange/what-is/ethereum).
